SENT.plain: Transcranial Doppler ultrasound (TCD) is commonly used to detect embolic signals in the cerebral circulation
However, current techniques to discriminate between signals from emboli and artifacts are subjective and ambiguous
The radiofrequency (RF) signal provides an extra dimension to the information available from conventional TCD systems that may help to interpret complex events
Artifacts generated by healthy volunteers and embolic signals recorded from a flow phantom were used to characterize the appearance of the two types of event
Characteristics of events, recorded during and immediately after carotid endarterectomy surgery, were compared with those from known sources
Additional information was provided by the RF signal on events recorded during TCD monitoring thus aiding classification
The RF signal may have a role as a "gold standard" for embolus detection
